Award.AwardTitle: RI: Doctoral Student Workshop at the Third Annual Conference on Advances in Cognitive Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Doctoral Student Workshop, co-located with the Third Annual Conference in Cognitive Systems, to be held at Atlanta (GA) in May 2015 aims at encouraging, expanding and guiding the participation of young researchers starting their research in cognitive computing. The Cognitive Systems conference attempts to foster research carried out in the original spirit of AI, which aimed to design and implement computer programs that exhibited the breadth, generality, and flexibility often observed in human intelligence. Cognitive computing recently has major successes represented by well known systems like IBM Watson program and Apple Siri program among many others.

The conference sessions and workshops will help develop human research capital by enabling interactions between senior and junior researchers and catalyzing new collaborations. The doctoral student workshop will increase the exposure and visibility of young graduate student researchers in these areas, and train them by providing early input and feedback in the field in an interactive and constructive environment. The workshop is aimed at early- to mid-career PhDs, specifically those in their second and third year of their PhD.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mentoring of young researchers is critical for the maintenance and growth of any scientific research community, including the cognitive systems research community. This project supported three young cognitive systems researchers in organizing a Student Workshop as part of the Third Annual Conference on Advances in Cognitive Systems (ACS 2015) held in Atlanta, Georgia in May 2015. Nine other Ph.D. students, selected by the workshop organizers, gave talks to the workshop and received critical feedback on their research at an early stage. All twelve students came from US universities such as Georgia Tech, North Carolina State University, Northwestern University, University of California at Santa Cruz, and University of Michigan.

The Student Workshop at ACS 2015 also included several senior cognitive systems researchers, included two invited speakers and two panelists. All twelve young researchers also participated in the main cognitive systems conference. This enabled the twelve young cognitive systems researchers to network with one another as well as with the broader cognitive systems research community. It also exposed them to cutting edge research in cognitive systems. We expect the twelve researchers to become part of the growing cognitive systems research community and to contribute for years, perhaps decades.

Details of the conference are available at http://www.cogsys.org/conference/2015. Details of the workshop are available at http://www.cogsys.org/2015-student-workshop.
